prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: GOODS-S Band 6 map - WEST
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 147-pointing mosaic of a region of West end of GOODS-S CANDELS in Band 6

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: As this is a continuum survey we opt for the TDM correlator setup giving us 4x128 dual-polarisation channels over a 7.5-GHz usable bandwidth. The spectral resolution in this mode is sufficient for us to identify strong emission lines with widths characteristic of gas motions within galaxies.

This is primarily a detection experiment and we thus adopt a resolution of 0.5" roughly matched to the expected sizes of the sources (Simpson et al. 2015; Ikarashi et al. 2015). This resolution is provided by C36-3 array configuration (although the slightly coarser resolution available from C36-2 would be equally acceptable), which has a maximum sensitive scale of 12", no shadowing is expected on our Dec=-27 target.
We place our survey area on the deepest area of imaging from the CANDELS HST legacy project (Fig. 1), surrounding the ~15x smaller (but deeper) ALMA band 6 survey of the UDF partly completed in Cycle 2 (PI: Dunlop). This region is covered by the Chandra 7Ms (PI: Brandt) and deep JVLA 3 and 6GHz observations (PI: Rujopakarn), as well as containing ~2500 photometric-z/spectroscopic-z galaxies and AGN, ~250 MIPS/radio/FIR/submm sources (see Fig. 1). Experience from brighter SMG surveys (e.g. Hodge et al. 2013; Simpson et al. 2015) suggests modest levels of overlap between the submm population and these different multi-wavelength samples, but demonstrate clearly that it is rarely obvious from their non-FIR/submm properties, which will turn out to the be FIR-luminous examples. In addition to direct detections, we will obtain statistical estimates of the FIR-luminosities of these populations through stacking: yielding 3-sigma limits on sub-samples of 20 and 100 sources of 0.06 and 0.03mJy, equivalent to 7e10Lo in the latter case. Finally, the single-dish 1.2mm survey of this region by Scott et al. (2010) using AzTEC on ASTE has a 60" FWHM beam and a 1-sigma rms of 0.56mJy and detect no sources brighter than 3.1mJy (deboosted). If the brightest of these sources comprise single SMGs, then we will detect them at high significance, 20-30 sigma.

We aim to balance the area coverage of our continuum survey with sensitivity to high-redshift dust SEDs and the efficiency and available weather statistics for ALMA. We therefore adopt a 254-pointing in Band 6 (221 GHz) with an area of 48.5 sq. arcmin. To detect sources with typical LIRG-like FIR luminosities of ~6.e11Lo, we require to reach 221 GHz (1.3mm) fluxes of ~0.3mJy at z~1.5 (corresponding to 345GHz/870um fluxes of ~1.1mJy, fainter than any source detected in the Hodge et al. 2013 or Simpson et al. 2015 surveys). We expect ~120 sources at this limit in our survey area (Figs. 1 & 2). To detect this flux at 3.5-sigma significance over the whole field we then require an average rms of 0.09mJy. Using the OT a 147-pointing sub-region in our survey (corresponding to the western part of the field, Fig.1) at 221GHz to 0.09mJy rms requires 4.1hr on-source, 3.0hr of calibration and overheads, meaning 7.1hr is needed to complete this part and leading to a total request of 12.4hrs for the whole mosaic.
As noted, at 221 GHz our contiguous 254-pointing mosaic has an area of 48.5 sq. arcmin above the half-power contour, using a hexagonal grid with FWHM-beam offsets. We have selected this larger inter-pointing offset based on experience with the variation in map depths between good-quality, QA2-passed maps. So for example in the good-quality Cycle 1 observations of Simpson et al. (2015), the sensitivity of the QA2-passed maps in a single SB varied by 11% rms. Hence a completely uniform map is unachievable and instead we adopt a larger inter-pointing spacing to increase the area coverage, without exceeding the expected pointing-to-pointing variance. Our proposed map thus has an average sensitivity of 1.13+/-0.05 compared to a single-pointing.

Our adopted frequency coverage is selected to maximise the number of sources with existing precise spectroscopic redshifts within the mosaic where we can search for low/moderate-J CO emission within our frequency range (mostly these are CO(4-3) or CO(3-2)). Our choice of 221 GHz allows us to search for CO emission in 112 sources in our field, 37 having CO(3-2) at z~0.6 and 56 with CO(4-3) at z~1.1. We will search for emission in individual sources, but view this as unlikely.
Hence, in addition to direct detections, we will stack the restframe ALMA spectra of the 112 sources with precise spectroscopic redshifts. Assuming these sources are not individually detected in the continuum then for the ~40-60 examples each at z~0.6 or z~1.1 we estimate a limit on the stacked FIR-luminosity of of 8.e10Lo (or a dust mass of 1.e7Mo) implying an H2 mass of 1e9Mo for a dust-gas ratio of 90 (Swinbank et al. 2014). Assuming a 200km/s line, a MW-like alpha_CO and r32/r43~0.5 (Bothwell et al. 2013) the stacked restframe CO spectrum for these two sub-sets of sources would have a 1-sigma sensitivity of 15mJy/km/s and so could in principle detect the CO emission in these spectra at ~4 sigma. This will be sufficient to provide a representative star-formation efficiency for the FIR-selected LIRG population to compare to that derived for ULIRGs or UV-selected galaxy populations.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: GOODS-S Band 6 map - EAST
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 107-pointing mosaic of a region of East end of GOODS-S CANDELS in Band 6

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: As this is a continuum survey we opt for the TDM correlator setup giving us 4x128 dual-polarisation channels over a 7.5-GHz usable bandwidth. The spectral resolution in this mode is sufficient for us to identify strong emission lines with widths characteristic of gas motions within galaxies.

This is primarily a detection experiment and we thus adopt a resolution of 0.5" roughly matched to the expected sizes of the sources (Simpson et al. 2015; Ikarashi et al. 2015). This resolution is provided by C36-3 array configuration (although the slightly coarser resolution available from C36-2 would be equally acceptable), which has a maximum sensitive scale of 12", no shadowing is expected on our Dec=-27 target.
We place our survey area on the deepest area of imaging from the CANDELS HST legacy project (Fig. 1), surrounding the ~15x smaller (but deeper) ALMA band 6 survey of the UDF partly completed in Cycle 2 (PI: Dunlop). This region is covered by the Chandra 7Ms (PI: Brandt) and deep JVLA 3 and 6GHz observations (PI: Rujopakarn), as well as containing ~2500 photometric-z/spectroscopic-z galaxies and AGN, ~250 MIPS/radio/FIR/submm sources (see Fig. 1). Experience from brighter SMG surveys (e.g. Hodge et al. 2013; Simpson et al. 2015) suggests modest levels of overlap between the submm population and these different multi-wavelength samples, but demonstrate clearly that it is rarely obvious from their non-FIR/submm properties, which will turn out to the be FIR-luminous examples. In addition to direct detections, we will obtain statistical estimates of the FIR-luminosities of these populations through stacking: yielding 3-sigma limits on sub-samples of 20 and 100 sources of 0.06 and 0.03mJy, equivalent to 7e10Lo in the latter case. Finally, the single-dish 1.2mm survey of this region by Scott et al. (2010) using AzTEC on ASTE has a 60" FWHM beam and a 1-sigma rms of 0.56mJy and detect no sources brighter than 3.1mJy (deboosted). If the brightest of these sources comprise single SMGs, then we will detect them at high significance, 20-30 sigma.

We aim to balance the area coverage of our continuum survey with sensitivity to high-redshift dust SEDs and the efficiency and available weather statistics for ALMA. We therefore adopt a 254-pointing in Band 6 (221 GHz) with an area of 48.5 sq. arcmin. To detect sources with typical LIRG-like FIR luminosities of ~6.e11Lo, we require to reach 221 GHz (1.3mm) fluxes of ~0.3mJy at z~1.5 (corresponding to 345GHz/870um fluxes of ~1.1mJy, fainter than any source detected in the Hodge et al. 2013 or Simpson et al. 2015 surveys). We expect ~120 sources at this limit in our survey area (Figs. 1 & 2). To detect this flux at 3.5-sigma significance over the whole field we then require an average rms of 0.09mJy. Using the OT this 107-pointing element of our survey (corresponding to the eastern-half of our survey field, Fig.1) at 221GHz to 0.09mJy rms requires 3.1hr on-source, 2.2hr of calibration and overheads, leading to a request of 5.3hrs for this science goal (and a total request of 12.4hr for the whole mosaic). We have excised ~30 pointings from this sub-mosaic to ensure we minimise overlap (<10% of the area of the smaller mosaic) with the UDF mosaic which is currently in progress.
As noted, at 221 GHz our contiguous 254-pointing mosaic has an area of 48.5 sq. arcmin above the half-power contour, using a hexagonal grid with FWHM-beam offsets. We have selected this larger inter-pointing offset based on experience with the variation in map depths between good-quality, QA2-passed maps. So for example in the good-quality Cycle 1 observations of Simpson et al. (2015), the sensitivity of the QA2-passed maps in a single SB varied by 11% rms. Hence a completely uniform map is unachievable and instead we adopt a larger inter-pointing spacing to increase the area coverage, without exceeding the expected pointing-to-pointing variance. Our proposed map thus has an average sensitivity of 1.13+/-0.05 compared to a single-pointing.

Our adopted frequency coverage is selected to maximise the number of sources with existing precise spectroscopic redshifts within the mosaic where we can search for low/moderate-J CO emission within our frequency range (mostly these are CO(4-3) or CO(3-2)). Our choice of 221 GHz allows us to search for CO emission in 112 sources in our field, 37 having CO(3-2) at z~0.6 and 56 with CO(4-3) at z~1.1. We will search for emission in individual sources, but view this as unlikely.
Hence, in addition to direct detections, we will stack the restframe ALMA spectra of the 112 sources with precise spectroscopic redshifts. Assuming these sources are not individually detected in the continuum then for the ~40-60 examples each at z~0.6 or z~1.1 we estimate a limit on the stacked FIR-luminosity of 8.e10Lo (or a dust mass of 1.e7Mo) implying an H2 mass of 1e9Mo for a dust-gas ratio of 90 (Swinbank et al. 2014). Assuming a 200km/s line, a MW-like alpha_CO and r32/r43~0.5 (Bothwell et al. 2013) the stacked restframe CO spectrum for these two sub-sets of sources would have a 1-sigma sensitivity of 15mJy/km/s and so could in principle detect the CO emission in these spectra at ~4 sigma. This will be sufficient to provide a representative star-formation efficiency for the FIR-selected LIRG population to compare to that derived for ULIRGs or UV-selected galaxy populations.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Luminous infrared galaxies (LIRGs, L_IR>1e11Lo) are the main contributor to star formation at z>1. Constraining their physical properties is thus critical for understanding how galaxies form and evolve. However, the confusion limit of previous FIR/mm facilities (mostly single-dish) did not allow their direct detection, and previous interferometer surveys only detect a few sources, insufficient to characterize the population. ALMA's unparalleled mapping capability can transform this: We propose to map ~50 arcmin^2 in GOODS-S/CANDELS (the deepest/large multiwavelength field in the south) to 90uJy rms at 1.3mm to detect >100 LIRGs. This unique survey will determine the evolution in the volume density of LIRGs, the role of AGN in their energetics (using 7-Ms Chandra image) and their HST structural properties (from CANDELS), contrasting these with ULIRGs. We will also probe >2000 less luminous star-forming galaxies & AGN by stacking their 1.3mm flux. This proposal will yield a rich dataset on key galaxy populations in this unparalleled field for the community to exploit - placing LIRGs in their evolutionary setting relative to both rarer ULIRGs and more numerous main-sequence galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: IRAM Grenoble, Institute of Millimetric Radioastronomy (IRAM)
Dept of Astronomy & Astrophysics, Pennsylvania State University
Department of Physics and Atmospheric Science, Dalhousie University
